SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He also experiences shortness of breath during physical activities and occasional chest cramps. He denies fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. The patient has been taking his medications and monitoring his blood pressure regularly. He admits to struggling with his diet due to recent home renovations.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Congestive heart failure
Hypertension

MEDICATIONS

Lasix
Lisinopril

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Fatigue and lightheadedness
Shortness of breath during physical activities
Occasional chest cramps
Slight cough

VITALS

Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation are within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters
Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur
Lungs: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally
Lower extremities: 1+ pitting edema

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation

ASSESSMENT

1. Congestive heart failure: Fluid retention
2. Hypertension: Well-managed

PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure:
   - Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day
   - Patient to weigh himself daily and report weight gain or shortness of breath
   - Order another echocardiogram
2. Hypertension:
   - Continue Lisinopril 20 mg a day
   - Patient to continue recording blood pressures at home and report elevated readings via patient portal

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will be contacted after test results are received.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 43-year-old female who presents for right knee pain. She reports falling off a ladder while changing a light bulb and twisting her knee during the fall. The incident occurred yesterday. The patient has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it has not provided significant relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Digoxin.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Knee: Tenderness over the medial portion of the right knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress.
• Sensation: Normal sensation in the lower extremity.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right knee demonstrates no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's history, physical examination, and x-ray findings are consistent with an acute medial meniscus sprain or strain.
• Medical Treatment: The patient will be placed in a knee brace and provided with crutches for temporary use. She will be prescribed Motrin 800 mg every six hours with food for two weeks. The patient will follow up in one week, and if there is no improvement, an MRI will be ordered.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. He presents today with lower back pain after lifting heavy boxes too quickly on Saturday morning. He heard a pop and experienced pain, which was relieved after lying down for an hour. The patient has been experiencing stiffness since the incident. He took Tylenol, ibuprofen, and used icy heat on the affected area, but it did not provide significant relief. He also experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon. The patient finds it difficult to find a comfortable sleeping position but lying on his right side seems to help.

The patient has been managing his diabetes, hypertension, and osteoarthritis with medications and monitoring. He admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He has been monitoring his blood pressure during the week but tends to forget on weekends.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Cardiovascular
• Auscultation of Heart: 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable compared to previous exams.

Musculoskeletal
• Examination of Back: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

Blood pressure is slightly elevated in the office.

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

Back X-ray: Normal, with good bony alignment and no fracture present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Back pain: Lumbar strain from lifting heavy boxes.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.

2. Diabetes: Slightly uncontrolled.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day, repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

3. Hypertension: Needs better control.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg a day.

4. Osteoarthritis: Stable, no further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam, depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports doing well overall, with his depression managed on Prozac. He has been experiencing some difficulty with hypertension, but his blood pressure has been improving. Ralph endorses nasal congestion due to pollen and shortness of breath with exertion during his morning runs. He runs 4-5 miles daily. No other significant symptoms were reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 120/80.

Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Extremities: No lower extremity edema.

Head and Neck: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.

Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT

1. Depression - stable on Prozac.
2. Hypertension - improving, continue current medication.
3. Prior lobectomy - no concerning findings on chest X-ray, good exercise tolerance.
4. Systolic ejection murmur - order echocardiogram.

PLAN

1. Depression: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
2. Hypertension: Encourage medication adherence, continue Norvasc.
3. Prior lobectomy: No further follow-up with surgeon needed.
4. Systolic ejection murmur: Order echocardiogram and follow up with results.
5. Order routine blood work.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will be contacted through the patient portal with results and any necessary follow-up.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents with right index finger pain following a skiing accident four days ago. The patient reports that while skiing, she attempted to jump over moguls and got her strap caught on her finger, causing it to bend back. She has tried applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but the pain persists. The pain is worse with movement.

Ms. Brooks also reports a history of constipation, for which she takes Miralax. She had an appendectomy at age 18.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Right index finger: Tenderness over the distal phalanx and the joint. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right hand: No fractures identified. Everything lines up well.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female presenting with right index finger pain following a skiing accident.

Right index finger contusion:
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has tenderness over the distal phalanx and joint, with pain during flexion. X-ray shows no fractures.
• Medical Treatment: Provide an aluminum foam splint for support. Prescribe Motrin 600 mg every six hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient should return for further evaluation.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 65-year-old female who presents for evaluation of iron deficiency anemia. She was diagnosed with anemia in 12-2019 when she was unable to donate blood. She has been anemic since she was 13 years old. The patient reports fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also experiences increased sensitivity to cold and worsening anxiety and depression. The patient had a hysterectomy in 1996 and a colonoscopy 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive for fatigue, feverishness, and chills.
• Respiratory: Positive for shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Positive for headaches.
• Psychiatric: Positive for anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General Examination: Normal without any significant findings.
• Cardiovascular: Heart sounds normal.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen soft, non-tender.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

• Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
• Over-the-counter Vitamin B12.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 65-year-old female who presents for evaluation of iron deficiency anemia.

Iron Deficiency Anemia
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of anemia since she was 13 years old. The cause of her anemia is not yet determined.
• Additional Testing: Schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Referral: Send a referral to a hematologist (Dr. Flores) for further evaluation and management.
• Medical Treatment: Continue taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 8-12 weeks.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 52-year-old male who presented to his primary care provider with worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches. Brain MRI and serology were performed, revealing a pituitary lesion.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Unremarkable.

FAMILY HISTORY

Unknown, patient was adopted.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer.
Marital status: Married for 25 years.
Alcohol, tobacco, and drug use: None.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, rash, or neck stiffness.
Neurological: Reports headaches, bitemporal hemianopia, and bumping into door frames. Denies numbness, tingling, or passing out.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neurological
- Mental status: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent.
- Cranial nerves: Grossly intact.
- Motor and sensory: No focal deficits in upper or lower extremities.
- Visual acuity and eye movements: Normal.
- Pupils: Equal and reactive.
- Visual field testing: Bitemporal hemianopia.
- Color vision: Normal.

RESULTS
Imaging

MRI of the brain with contrast (3/4/21): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Pituitary adenoma.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient has a benign-appearing pituitary adenoma, discovered incidentally during workup for worsening headaches. He is symptomatic with clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.
- Surgical Intervention: Transsphenoidal approach to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa is indicated. The patient has been informed of the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery.
- Referrals: The patient will be referred to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field testing prior to surgery.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended surgical intervention plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with the surgery scheduler and eye doctor as directed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. No known family history of GI problems.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient was going through a stressful job transition around the time of the chest pain episode.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies current chest pain.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, reports normal bowel movements. Reports mild tenderness to light palpation in upper abdominal quadrants.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Neurological: Denies headache or dizziness.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in upper abdominal quadrants. No rebound or guarding.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient had a normal cardiac workup in the ER. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. Suspect anxiety attack related to job transition, plus or minus contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. Patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change.

INSTRUCTIONS

Patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints or if symptoms reoccur. Advised to call the office if any additional episodes of pain or other concerning symptoms arise.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic doctor, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The geneticist mentioned the possibility of kidney anomalies associated with the syndrome, prompting the current visit.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome
Reflux
Developmental delays

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Lives with her family in Dallas, Georgia. She has a twin sister and a 9-year-old brother with autism.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

MEDICATIONS

None.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
Eyes: Small appearing.
Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
Genitalia: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old former 34 and 3-week-old twin with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. Several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature. We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling after a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling after a fall. She reports that she was walking up and down the stairs while doing laundry when she slipped and tried to catch herself with her arms outstretched. The pain began immediately after the fall and has been severe, rated as a 9/10. She has been using ice, an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient is planning a vacation in a month.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right wrist pain and swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right wrist: Pain on flexion and extension. Pain with radial and ulnar deviation. Limited ability to make a fist. Swelling and bruising present. Tenderness on palpation throughout. Bony crepitus noted.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right wrist were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal a Colles' fracture with extra-articular involvement and ulnar styloid fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Right wrist Colles' fracture.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we had a discussion in regards to her current symptoms and treatment options. The patient will be given a brace for her right wrist and scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management and will begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery. The patient will wear the brace for six weeks and will have a follow-up appointment in a month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a 45-year-old male who presents with right knee pain for the past week after slipping and falling while working on his property. The patient reports feeling a pop during the fall and has experienced swelling and pain since the incident. He has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief. The pain is rated as 4/10 when moving the knee and minimal when stationary. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and is currently on 20mg of lisinopril.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Right Knee
Pain to palpation of the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema around the knee, and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-ray of Right Knee
Impression: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

• Right knee MCL strain
• Hypertension

PLAN

Right knee MCL strain
• Prescribe ibuprofen 800mg twice daily for pain and swelling.
• Provide a knee brace for support and stability.
• Recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day.
• Encourage elevation and rest for the affected leg.

Hypertension
• Continue lisinopril 20mg daily.
• Referral to nutritionist for dietary management and sodium reduction.
• Monitor blood pressure and adjust medication as needed.

INSTRUCTIONS

Return to clinic in 4 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain for three weeks.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a middle-aged male who presents with left shoulder pain for the past three weeks. He cannot recall any specific injury but has been active and recently doing work in his basement. He has had occasional aches and pains in the past, but nothing that Tylenol couldn't manage. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure or reaching for objects. He has been taking extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which provides some relief but not complete resolution of the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his arms or hands.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses left shoulder pain and limited range of motion.
• Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling in arms or hands.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Limited active and passive range of motion in the left shoulder. Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.
• Neurovascular: Capillary refill is less than three seconds in the left arm. Sensation is intact to light touch.

RESULTS

X-ray of the left shoulder demonstrates no fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has limited range of motion and tenderness in the left shoulder, with no fractures seen on x-ray.
• Additional Testing: Order an MRI of the left shoulder to further evaluate the rotator cuff and rule out other causes of pain.
• Medical Treatment: Continue taking Tylenol as needed for pain relief.
• Referral: Refer the patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks to help strengthen shoulder muscles and improve range of motion.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Discuss the possibility of a steroid injection if symptoms do not improve with physical therapy. Schedule a follow-up visit after completing physical therapy.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a patient presenting with occasional left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that the knee occasionally gives out while walking, but the pain passes quickly. The patient denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any medication for the pain. The patient is concerned about an upcoming trip involving walking and dancing and is hesitant to participate due to the knee issue.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses left knee pain and instability.
• Cardiovascular: Patient is on medication for hypertension.
• Endocrine: Patient has diabetes mellitus and is on medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.
• Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.
• Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Left Knee: No ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee X-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain and instability.
   • Medical Reasoning: Suspect arthritis in the left knee.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently on lisinopril for hypertension.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily and order an echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.

3. Diabetes Mellitus.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently on metformin for diabetes.
   • Medical Treatment: Order hemoglobin A1c to assess if adjustments to metformin are needed. Order lipid panel.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up for a 53-year-old female with stage three non-small cell lung cancer during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule. Biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and no shortness of breath
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting, reports sore throat
Psychiatric: Reports feeling emotionally and mentally strong with good support from family and nursing staff

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Stable, oxygen saturation within normal limits
Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
Respiratory: Crackles in lungs bilaterally
Skin: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, possibly related to radiation
Lower Extremities: No edema

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer
- Medical Reasoning: Continue with the current regimen of chemotherapy (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess tumor size and potential for surgical removal.
2. Radiation pneumonitis
- Medical Reasoning: The cough and possible shortness of breath may be related to the radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe a low dose of prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to help reduce inflammation and allow the patient to continue with radiation therapy.
3. Painful swallowing
- Medical Reasoning: Inflammation in the esophagus may be causing the patient's sore throat and difficulty swallowing.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow to be used four times a day to help with swallowing and prevent dehydration and further weight loss.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Patient referred for evaluation of low immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports frequent colds during the winter months that tend to linger for a long time. No recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. The patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

The patient reports no known family history of immune deficiencies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever or unintentional weight loss.
Respiratory: Reports frequent colds during winter months.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal infections or diarrhea.
Endocrine: Recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Within normal limits, no fever.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs appreciated.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, no masses or organomegaly.

LABORATORY DATA

The patient's recent lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. The patient does not report frequent infections or other symptoms that would suggest a more severe immunodeficiency.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained to the patient that IgA deficiency is a common immunodeficiency and that most people with this condition live normal lives without complications. I advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or become difficult to control, as well as any changes in their abdominal tract, such as severe diarrhea.
- Medical Treatment: I will order additional blood work to check for other antibodies and immunodeficiencies. I advised the patient to inform any healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they require blood products in the future.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I discussed the importance of managing their diabetes through lifestyle modifications, including diet and exercise. I encouraged the patient to monitor their blood sugar levels and follow up with their primary care provider as needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a patient who presents with a 4-day history of right elbow pain, which he attributes to increased pottery activity during the pandemic. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. He rates the pain as a 6/10 and reports that it interferes with his daily activities and sleep. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

PAST HISTORY

No prior elbow injuries.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
Right elbow: Positive for pain to palpation, moderate tenderness of the medial epicondyle. Positive for pain with pronation of the forearm and resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

1. Rest and immobilization: Order a sling for the patient to wear while awake.
2. Ice application: Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Medication: Ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for one week.
4. Activity modification: Advise the patient to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week to assess progress.

INSTRUCTIONS

Wear the sling as instructed, apply ice, take ibuprofen as prescribed, and avoid pottery work. Return for a follow-up appointment in one week. Call the clinic with any additional concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain, shortness of breath, and ankle swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of chest pain, shortness of breath, and ankle swelling. He reports that he fell down while walking outside and experienced chest pain, which he initially dismissed as heartburn. He also reports shortness of breath and ankle swelling. The patient was recently in the emergency department and had an echocardiogram.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a history of hypertension and is on medication for it. He reports occasionally missing doses.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports quitting smoking a couple of years ago but still has one cigarette per week.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain and shortness of breath.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports ankle swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Blood pressure 128/72.
Neck: No jugular venous distention.
Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
Lower extremities: Trace edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain, shortness of breath, and ankle swelling likely due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.

PLAN

1. Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily.
2. Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily.
3. Continue Norvasc 5 mg once daily.
4. Consult with a nutritionist to improve diet and reduce salt intake.
5. Obtain a home blood pressure cuff and monitor blood pressure regularly.
6. Obtain a scale and weigh daily; call the clinic if there is a weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.
7. Order a renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.
8. Encourage the patient to take medications consistently and follow up with the nutritionist.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with the clinic as needed and report any significant changes in symptoms or weight gain. The patient is advised to take medications consistently, monitor blood pressure, and follow up with the nutritionist to improve diet.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sharp pain on the right side of the abdomen below the ribs for the last several days.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones (father).

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports sharp pain in the right lower abdomen, moving to the lower abdomen and groin. Pain comes and goes. Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. Denies frank blood in urine. Reports nausea but no vomiting.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen
- General Examination: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
- CVA Tenderness: Positive on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen: Revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and CT scan results are consistent with a kidney stone.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of pushing fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. Continue alternating with Tylenol. Provide a strainer for urine collection. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks. Discuss further treatment options (lithotripsy or ureteroscopy) if symptoms persist.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a male with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a non-healing foot ulcer on his right foot. He has had the ulcer for about six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The patient noticed a foul smell and yellow drainage from the wound. He has been on antibiotics for six days, with some improvement initially, but now the wound has turned black around the edges and he is experiencing cramping in his calf muscle. The patient also reports a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle and calf muscle, which is very hot. He has been experiencing coughing and shortness of breath in the past two days.

The patient's diabetes has been well-controlled with an A1C of 6.7. However, his blood sugars have been trending higher in the past two weeks, with some spikes up to 500.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
• Respiratory: Endorses coughing and shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses cramping in calf muscle.
• Integumentary: Non-healing foot ulcer with black edges and red streak up the leg.
• Endocrine: Diabetes with recent higher blood sugars.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
• Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the heel, approximately 2x2 cm, sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythema, and odor present. No bony exposure.
• Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.

RESULTS

Right foot x-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer:
• Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with a non-healing foot ulcer with signs of infection and possible vascular compromise.
• Diagnostic Testing: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
• Medical Treatment: Perform debridement in the office, obtain a culture, and consider changing antibiotic therapy based on culture results. Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf closely. Follow up in 7 days.

Diabetes management:
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood sugars have been trending higher recently, which may impact wound healing.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to closely monitor his blood sugars and maintain an A1C below 7.
• Medical Treatment: Follow up with the endocrinologist to adjust diabetes management as needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Tick bite on right knee.

HPI:

Mr. Richard is a middle-aged male who presents today for an evaluation of a tick bite on his right knee. He is unsure of when he got the tick bite but mentions spending time outdoors and hunting recently. The bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. He has not experienced fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and having a headache since the tick bite.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Lisinopril 20 mg once a day
Metformin 1000 mg twice a day

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Hypertension
Diabetes

EXAM:

Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows erythema, edema, and an area of fluctuance over the right patella. There is pain to palpation of the right anterior knee, but full range of motion is present. Skin examination reveals a bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

RESULTS:

Pending: Lyme titer, Western blot, lipid panel, hemoglobin A1c, basic metabolic panel.

IMPRESSION:

1. Possible Lyme disease
2. Hypertension
3. Diabetes

PLAN:

1. Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks for possible Lyme disease. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg once a day for hypertension. Order lipid panel to monitor cholesterol levels.
3. Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice a day for diabetes. Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

All questions were answered, and the patient will follow up as needed.
